awd_titl_txt: RI: Medium: Collaborative Research: A Structure-Math-Function Approach for Designing Robustly Intelligent Synthetic Nervous Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Robots are becoming integrated into more areas of life, no longer confined to the predictable environment of a factory, performing the same task. Robots that work among humans require greater intelligence and the ability to adapt to changing tasks in an unpredictable environment. This work develops a sophisticated control system for robotics by modeling the control systems in the brain of a remarkably intelligent, capable, and adaptable insect: the praying mantis. This work promises to transform our understanding of intelligence in both robotics and neuroscience. A model of decision-making in the relatively simple brains of insects advances the study of more complex brains. The model will then be used to allow a legged robot to adapt its movement to suit its goals such as assisting humans, or its "needs" such as seeking energy or avoiding danger. These advances seek to give robots the autonomy that animals have. Instead of being programmed for every possible situation, a robot could be trained, continue to learn from experience, and improve efficiency even in novel situations. At an after-school robotics program at an inner-city school, students will benefit from hands-on experience creating robots with the unique perspective of bio-inspired design and modeling of nervous systems.  

This work expands the scale and sophistication of a synthetic nervous system (SNS), a continuous time dynamical model of praying mantis nervous system, and applies it to robotic control. Multi-channel neural recording and stimulation techniques are revealing how insects simplify motor control by distributing computation throughout the nervous system. This project leverages these techniques to understand how the capability of the "higher" level (the brain, where sensory input is processed) is directly supported by intelligence in the "lower" level (ganglia that coordinate the legs). These data will be used to develop and implement an SNS to control the six-legged MantisBot, endowing it with online learning and intelligent autonomy. Neurobiology will inform this work in all three specific aims: 1) Investigate the lower-level intelligence of the mantis nervous system and use the results to increase the intelligence of MantisBot's low-level control networks; 2) Investigate the correlation between descending commands and behavior and use the results to develop a simplified brain (i.e. high-level controller) for MantisBot; and 3) Investigate the effect of conflicting visual inputs (e.g. simultaneous prey and predator) on descending commands, and use these findings to endow MantisBot with robust intelligence distributed throughout its SNS.

por.por_cntn:
This grant enhanced our understanding of (1) how nervous systems can be modeled, (2) how insect nervous systems control their legs, (3) how animal nervous systems work in general, and (4) how this knowledge can be used to advance control of robots. Thanks to this grant we are several steps closer to being able to train robots that continue to learn from experience, and improve efficiency even in novel situations. These are capabilities that are essential for a robot than can perform a variety of important tasks such as elder care and exploration and search and rescue in hazardous situations. As part of this grant, members of our team hosted classes of primarily African American K-12 students with hands-on experiences creating robots to perform particular tasks during annual summer programs.


We shared our findings with the academic community and the public through 23 refereed publications and many more abstracts and poster presentations at various scientific meetings. We also developed and shared software tools through GitHub.


We advanced a computational neuroscience method that produces what are called “synthetic nervous systems” or SNS. An SNS can model parts of an animal’s nervous system and be used to conduct experiments in software to better understand how the nervous system functions. SNS can also be used to control robots. An SNS is based on the structure of an animal’s nervous system and other data discovered by neuroscientists. However, typically much is still unknown. Thus, we use the “functional subnetwork approach” to design components of the SNS so that it functions like the animal’s nervous system. We extended this method originally developed for non-spiking neurons for tuning networks of spiking neurons. We can now assemble and tune networks of spiking neurons and non-spiking neurons based on the network's intended function, without the use of global optimization or machine learning. To help model nervous systems, we developed an open-source Python software package called SNS-Toolbox, which can simulate hundreds to thousands of spiking and non-spiking neurons in real-time or faster on consumer-grade computer hardware. This software reduced the barrier to entry for designing SNS networks, and should increase the prevalence of SNS networks in modeling and robotic control.


We advanced animal-inspired robust intelligence in many ways. Like mammals, insects contextually integrate received sensory information from their head sensors and their internal state, formulate appropriate behavioral responses, and send signals to their ventral nerve cord, similar to vertebrate spinal cord, that then carries out the behaviors. We created a simplified neural model of components within the central part of the insect brain called the central complex. This model recreated neuronal behavior such as correlating body rotation direction and speed to particular neural activity as has been recorded in insects.  We analyzed behavior sequences of freely hunting praying mantises to explore how their behavior correlated with their hunger. Starved praying mantises are more attentive to prey and more attentive to prey that is farther away from them. With reduced hunger, praying mantises showed reduced time in these behaviors. Our data demonstrates that during states of starvation, the praying mantis exhibits a stereotyped pattern of behavior that is highly motivated by prey capture.


We investigated how information is communicated between the ventral nerve cord (VNC) and the brain to facilitate control. We investigated how systems traditionally described as 'positive feedback' may initiate and maintain stepping in the VNC with limited information exchanged between the VNC and brain. We created a data-based model that shows that fruit flies choose their leg coordination (gait) based on their stability and their speed. We showed that slow muscle fibers increase the accuracy of limb positioning, even for motions much shorter than the relaxation time of the fiber, which is counter intuitive. We demonstrated a neural architecture that enables the control of stance phase speed, independent of swing phase amplitude or duration, which is what is observed in animals. Control of forces is essential in both animals and walking machines. Insects measure forces as strains in their exoskeletons via campaniform sensilla (CS). We characterized a model that predicts CS discharge, in which discharge is proportional to the instantaneous stimulus force relative to an adaptive variable.


We developed a robot that models the legged locomotion of the fruit fly, Drosophila. Drosophibot is a testbed for neural controllers developed in the grant that model the anatomy and function of the insect nervous system. As such, Drosophibot was designed to capture important features of the animal's biomechanics. We developed an SNS walking controller based on data from insects and showed that capturing more details in the animal’s nervous system improves control.


We also published a historical perspective on how the study of the neuromechanics of insects and other arthropods has inspired the construction, and especially the control, of hexapod robots.
